intro: Agapetes trianguli, commonly known as the three-angled silverleaf, is a species of evergreen shrub native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the Ericaceae family, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its small, leathery leaves. The plant typically grows in high-altitude cloud forests, where it thrives in cool, moist environments. Its flowers are usually white or pale pink, and it produces small, edible berries. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
